bullets: AI is reshaping industries from healthcare to transportation
Global AI market expected to reach $1.8 trillion by 2030

AI research publications have increased 300% in the last decade

segments.title: AI Policy and Regulation
segments.subtitle: Balancing Innovation and Protection
bullets: EU AI Act: World's first comprehensive AI regulation framework
Risk-based approach: minimal, limited, high-risk, and unacceptable
Focus on transparency, accountability, and human oversight
China's AI governance emphasizes state control and social stability
US adopts sector-specific approach with voluntary frameworks

media.caption: Timeline of major AI policy developments worldwide

segments.notes: Highlight different regulatory philosophies: EU (rights-based), China (state-centric), US (market-driven)

segments.title: AI in Healthcare
segments.subtitle: Transforming Medicine, Saving Lives
bullets: AI-powered diagnostics achieve 94% accuracy in detecting certain cancers
Drug discovery accelerated: compounds identified in months vs. years
Personalized medicine: treatment plans tailored to individual genetics
Predictive analytics: identifying at-risk patients before symptoms appear
Challenges: data privacy, algorithmic bias, physician-AI collaboration

media.caption: Deep learning model detecting diabetic retinopathy

segments.notes: Emphasize both promise and caution. Mention FDA approvals. Discuss patient consent.

segments.title: Autonomous Vehicles
segments.subtitle: Steering Toward an AI-Driven Future
bullets: Self-driving technology could prevent 90% of traffic accidents
Multiple levels: Level 0 (none) to Level 5 (full autonomy)
Currently at Level 2-3: driver assistance and conditional automation
Key challenges: edge cases, liability, ethical dilemmas (trolley problem)
Expected market adoption: commercial fleets before consumer vehicles

media.caption: Waymo autonomous taxi operating in San Francisco

engagement.prompt: In an unavoidable accident, how should an autonomous vehicle decide who to save?

citations.label: SAE Levels of Driving Automation
The Moral Machine Experiment - Nature
Autonomous Vehicles: Safety, Liability & Regulation

segments.notes: Discuss current deployments (Waymo, Cruise). Address safety statistics. Explore ethical frameworks.

segments.title: Algorithmic Fairness
segments.subtitle: Ensuring AI is Just and Inclusive
bullets: AI systems can perpetuate and amplify existing societal biases
Facial recognition: higher error rates for women and people of color
Credit scoring: discriminatory outcomes despite race-blind algorithms
Hiring AI: may discriminate based on protected characteristics
Solutions: diverse training data, fairness metrics, algorithmic audits

media.alt: Chart showing facial recognition error rates across demographics
media.caption: Demographic disparities in facial recognition accuracy

engagement.prompt: Is it possible to create truly unbiased AI, or should we focus on transparent bias?

citations.label: Gender Shades: Bias in Commercial Facial Recognition - MIT
Fairness and Abstraction in Sociotechnical Systems
Algorithmic Accountability: A Primer - Data & Society
EU Guidelines on Trustworthy AI

segments.notes: Use concrete examples. Discuss ProPublica's COMPAS investigation. Emphasize ongoing nature of fairness work.

segments.title: AI and Society: A Vision for the Future
segments.subtitle: Shaping Tomorrow Together
bullets: AI will augment human capabilities, not replace human judgment
Critical needs: AI literacy, workforce reskilling, equitable access
Governance frameworks must be adaptive and multistakeholder
Focus on human-centered AI: designed for people, by diverse teams
The future of AI depends on the choices we make today
